title: What started the age of exploration? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Age of Exploration is a kind of informal, or it should be, description of European moving across the world starting in the mid fifteenth century. It lasted about two hundred years after which most places had been “discovered”. Or what was going on was not “exploring” in the sense of seeing what was out there so much as going out to what was known and occasionally finding more stuff. But there was Capt. Cook’s voyage who found places which others may have found earlier but the word didn’t get out or nobody was or could afford to be interested. A good round up is Parry, “The Age of Reconnaisance” It’s about the European movement 1450–1650. Lots to do with development of deep sea sailing, navigation, voyages, etc. Problem is, people had been discovering things all over the world for a very long time. Whether there was a concerted, or loosely organized, or coincidental arrangement of several countries with a goal of exploration—as opposed to exploitation, trade, war, conquest, or getting lost,, you probably won’t find. In the eighteenth century, and early nineteenth, European navies discovered—for Europeans, lots of people if only the natives living there knew about them—while on the usual naval duties. Once in a while, a naval expedition if only one ship was directed to find out what was….south and more south and…..there was Antarctica. But see Parry.
